lines.text: People put you down enough, you start to believe it.
I think you are a very bright, very special woman.
The bad stuff is easier to believe. You ever notice that?
You're late.
You're stunning.
You're forgiven.
[after negotiating three thousand dollars]
I would have stayed for two thousand.
I would have paid four.
Hello, can I help you?
I was in here yesterday, you wouldn't wait on me.
Oh.
You people work on commission, right?
Yeah.
Big mistake. Big. Huge. I have to go shopping now.
Did you like the opera, dear?
It was so good, I almost peed my pants!
She said she liked it better than Pirates of Penzance.
I want the fairy tale.
I told you not to pick up the phone.
Then stop calling me.
I never treated you like a prostitute.
[Walks away]
You just did.
You can't charge me for directions!
I can do anything I want to baby, I ain't lost.
Fifty bucks, Grandpa. For seventy-five, the wife can watch.
It must be difficult to let go of something so beautiful.
That would make you a... lawyer.
What makes you think I'm a lawyer?
You have that sharp, useless look about you.
[Kit is trying to cheer up Vivian]
Tell me one person who it's worked out for.
What, you want me to name someone? You want like a name? Oh, God, the pressure of a name... I got it. Cindafuckin'rella
Let's watch old movies all night... we'll just veg out in front of the TV.
Veg out?
Yeah. Be still like vegetables. Lay like broccoli.
Look, I'll tell ya what. I'll be back. We'll do broccoli tomorrow.

People's reactions to opera the first time they see it is very dramatic; they either love it or they hate it. If they love it, they will always love it. If they don't, they may learn to appreciate it, but it will never become part of their soul.
I'm a sure thing.
I'm gonna treat you so nice, you're never gonna let me go.
Do you have anything in this shop as beautiful as she is?
[after meeting Vivian]
She's wonderful! Where ever did you find her?
976-BABE.
So what happens after he climbs up and rescues her?
She rescues him right back.
Bridge? He's not really my uncle.
They never are dear.
I think we both know she's not my niece.
Of course.
And the reason I know that is that I'm an only child.
Well, color me happy! There's a sofa in here for two!
[last lines]

Welcome to Hollywood! What's your dream? Everybody comes here; this is Hollywood, land of dreams. Some dreams come true, some don't; but keep on dreamin' - this is Hollywood. Always time to dream, so keep on dreamin'.
[At the beginning of the evening]
In case I forget to tell you later, I had a really good time tonight.
Edward is our most eligible bachelor, everyone is trying to land him.
Oh, I'm not trying to land him, I'm just using him for sex.
Just how obscene an amount of cash are we talking about here? Profane or really offensive?
Really offensive.
I like him so much.
6 nights at $300 is $1800
You want days too.
Done.
Can I call you Eddie?
Not if you expect me to answer.

[Vivian slips an escargot while having dinner with Edward and Mr. Morse]
Oops... slippery little suckers.
Impossible relationships. My special gift is impossible relationships.

[sitting with Edward leaning against her in the bathtub]
Did I mention, my leg is 44" from hip to toe. So basically we are talking about 88" of therapy, wrapped around you for the bargain price of $3000 dollars.
Wake up! Time to shop.
You and I are such similar creatures, Vivian. We both screw people for money.
Oh, Phil! About your car.
Oh, God! What?
It corners like it's on rails.
Are you sure you want me to stay the night? I mean, I could just pop ya real good and get outta here.
No, I'd really like you to stay. I don't want to be alone tonight.
Is it your birthday?
No, no. Not my birthday.
Oh. 'Cause you know, I've been the surprise at a lot of birthday parties.
I'll bet you have.
It's just that, uh, very few people surprise me.
Yeah, well, you're lucky. Most of 'em shock the hell outta me.
You should go for him. You look hot tonight. Don't take less than $100. Call me when you're through. Take care of you.
Take care of you.
What's your name?
What do you want it to be?
You make $100 an hour and you have a safety pin holding your boot up?
what's going on
I don't know, you left and suddenly I'm in the middle of The West Side Story

[Edward and Vivian are bargaining about Vivian's "Salary" at the end of the week]
$2,000
Done
Holy shit!
So, what's your name?
Edward.
Really? That's my favorite name in the whole world.
How much for the entire night?
Stay here? You couldn't afford it.
Try me.
300 dollars.
Done! Thank you. Now we can relax.

When I was a little girl, my mama used to lock me in the attic when I was bad, which was pretty often. And I would- I would pretend I was a princess... trapped in a tower by a wicked queen. And then suddenly this knight... on a white horse with these colors flying would come charging up and draw his sword. And I would wave. And he would climb up the tower and rescue me. But never in all the time... that I had this dream did the knight say to me, "Come on, baby, I'll put you up in a great condo."

[Sitting at a table, naked and only wearing a tie]
How was your day dear?
Nice tie!
I got it for you.
[Vivian calls Kit]
I called and called, where were you last night?
Ma?
Oh no, come on, you don't know that. Hey he asked you right? Maybe you guys could, like, um you know get a house together and, like, buy some diamonds and a horse. I don't know.
Edward. So how's it feel to be a trick?
I am not a trick. This is a trick. Darryl! Left pocket. Isn't that incredible? And he does have a permit. Thank you, gentlemen. - Don't you ever go near her again.
Does Darryl always carry a gun?
When he drives me, yes, always.

[referring to Philip Stuckey]
Real genuine guy. Who is he?
He's my lawyer. He's all right.
You could freeze ice on his wife's ass.
Maybe we'll try that later.

I got red, I got green, I got yellow... I'm out of purple, but I do have one Gold Circle coin left... the condom of champions... the one and only... nothin' is gettin' through this sucker. Whaddya say, hmm?
You know, you could pay me now, and break the ice.
Oh honey you know what's happened I got a runner in my pantyhose, I'm not wearing pantyhose.

[to Vivian]
I'd like you to spend the week with me.
So, do you have a wife? Girlfriend?
I have both.

[Watching a Horse Match]
Well done!
Well done! WOO! WOO! WOO!

[after Edward catches her singing along to Prince]
Don't you just love Prince?
More than life itself.
[Kit is streetwalking]
Hey yo, baby!
How 'bout a freebie? It's my birthday.
Dream on!
What would it be like?
It would get you off of the street.
That's just geography.
Mr. Lewis and I are going to build ships together, great big ships.
You clean up real nice. You sure don't fit in down on the Boulevard lookin' like you do, not that you ever did.
Well, thanks, but it's easy to clean up when you got money.
[first lines]

No matter what they say, it's all about money. So let's imagine, ladies, that you're a savings and loan officer. Watch - one, two, three; see, you've got it all, and we've got nothing. You've got all four, take a look.
I think you have a lot of special gifts.
I am very angry with my father.
You and I are such similar creatures, Vivian. We both screw people for money.
A buffet of safety?
I'm a safety girl.
[Edward stands up]
All right, let's get one of these on ya.
He mortgaged everything he owns, right down to his underwear, to secure a loan from the bank.
I say who, I say when, I say...
[blubbering]
WHO.

[Kit is grabbing cocktail garnishes from bar]
This ain't a buffet, Kit.
